quiz.question: Choose true sentence about qmake:

answers.txt: It is possible to generate both - Makefile and .pro file - with the use of qmake.
Qmake can generate Makefile, but it is not possible to generate .pro file with qmake,
Qmake compiles the project.

quiz.hint: In the default mode, qmake will use the description in a project file to generate a Makefile, but it is also possible to use qmake to generate project files. Source: http://doc.qt.io/qt-4.8/qmake-running.html

quiz.question: Choose <font color='red'>false</font> sentence about QString.

answers.txt: QString stores the string with the use of 8-bits characters,
QString is implemented with the use of implicit sharing for the best memory usage and performance,
QString is the part of the QtCore module.

quiz.hint: QString stores a string of 16-bit QChars, where each QChar corresponds one Unicode 4.0 character. Source: http://doc.qt.io/qt-5/qstring.html

quiz.question: Choose  <font color='red'>false</font> sentence about Q_OBJECT macro.

answers.txt: Q_OBJECT macro must appear in the public section of the class,
Q_OBJECT macro requires that the class in which it appears derive from QObject,
Q_OBJECT macro is needed by classes that define signals and slots.

quiz.hint: The Q_OBJECT macro must appear in the private section of a class definition that declares its own signals and slots or that uses other services provided by Qt's meta-object system. Source: http://doc.qt.io/qt-5/qobject.html

quiz.question: The TEMPLATE variable in .pro file can have following values:

answers.txt: app, desktop, mobile,
app, lib, subdirs,
app, qt4, qt5,
app, debug, release.

quiz.hint: TEMPLATE can have values: app, lib, subdirs, vcapp, vclib, vcsubdirs. Source: http://doc.qt.io/qt-4.8/qmake-project-files.html

quiz.question: What happens when the object of class QObject is copied?

answers.txt: The QObject::objectName() is also copied and is identical for both objects,
All the signals/slot connections are transferred to the copy,
Itâ€™s impossible to copy the QObject and all its subclasses.

quiz.hint: QObject and all subclasses of QObject (direct or indirect) have their copy constructor and assignment operator disabled. Source: http://doc.qt.io/qt-5/object.html#identity-vs-value

quiz.question:
Qt5 introduces new style of connect with the use of function pointers, like presented below:
connect( slider, &QSlider::valueChanged, spinbox, &QSpinBox::setValue );
The old Qt4 style was using SIGNAL() and SLOT() macros:
connect(slider, SIGNAL(valueChanged(int)), spinbox, SLOT(setValue(int)));
One of the advantages of Qt5 style is that:

answers.txt: it allows to connect overloaded slots easier,
errors can be detected earlier, at compilation stage,
Q_OBJECT macro is not needed for signals and slots anymore.

quiz.hint:
Pros of new syntax:
- Compile time check of the existence of the signals and slot, of the types, or if the Q_OBJECT is missing.
- Argument can be by typedefs or with different namespace specifier, and it works.
- Possibility to automatically cast the types if there is implicit conversion (e.g. from QString to QVariant)
- It is possible to connect to any member function of QObject, not only slots.
Source: https://wiki.qt.io/New_Signal_Slot_Syntax

quiz.question: What is <font color='red'>impossible</font> regarding signals and slots?

answers.txt: Signal to signal connection,

Connecting signal with no parameter to the slot with parameter, like 
connect(slider, SIGNAL(updated()), spinbox, SLOT(valueChanged(int)));

Connecting signal with a parameter to the slot with no parameters, like 
connect(slider, SIGNAL(valueChanged(int)), spinbox, SLOT(update()));

quiz.hint: The signature of a signal must match the signature of the receiving slot. (In fact a slot may have a shorter signature than the signal it receives because it can ignore extra arguments.) Source: http://doc.qt.io/qt-5/signalsandslots.html

quiz.question: Q_GADGET macro:

answers.txt: allows to have signal and slots for the classes that do not inherit from QObject,
enables some features of QMetaObject, i.e. Q_ENUM, Q_PROPERTY and Q_INVOKABLE,
can be put only into the QObject subclasses.

quiz.hint: The Q_GADGET macro is a lighter version of the Q_OBJECT macro for classes that do not inherit from QObject but still want to use some of the reflection capabilities offered by QMetaObject. Q_GADGETs can have Q_ENUM, Q_PROPERTY and Q_INVOKABLE, but they cannot have signals or slots. Source: http://doc.qt.io/qt-5/qobject.html#Q_GADGET

quiz.question: When Qt program enters the event loop?

answers.txt: When the int main() is entered,
when QCoreApplication object is created,
when QApplication.exec() is called.

quiz.hint: int QApplication::exec() enters the main event loop and waits until exit() is called, then returns the value that was set to exit() (which is 0 if exit() is called via quit()). Source: http://doc.qt.io/qt-4.8/qapplication.html#exec

quiz.question: Choose <font color='red'>false</font> sentence about moc.

answers.txt: Moc is a Meta-Object Compiler,
Moc produces moc files, which are ordinary C++ files,
Moc is unable to implement signals and slots for class templates,
Moc expands #define-s normally, so type macros can be used as signal argument.

quiz.hint: Since moc doesn't expand #defines, type macros that take an argument will not work in signals and slots. Source: http://doc.qt.io/qt-4.8/moc.html#type-macros-cannot-be-used-for-signal-and-slot-parameters

quiz.question: QObjects organize themselves in object trees. It means that:

answers.txt: each QObject can have a list of parents and a list of children,
each QObject can have a parent and a list of children,
they are stored in memory with the use of binary tree.

quiz.hint: QObjects organize themselves in object trees. When you create a QObject with another object as parent, it's added to the parent's children() list, and is deleted when the parent is. Source: http://doc.qt.io/qt-4.8/objecttrees.html

quiz.question: What happens when the QObject-parent is deleted before its children?

answers.txt: There is a memory leak,
The children are deleted too,
The children' parent-pointers point to invalid location, so the program may crash.

quiz.hint: When you create a QObject with another object as parent, it's added to the parent's children() list, and is deleted when the parent is. It turns out that this approach fits the needs of GUI objects very well. For example, a QShortcut (keyboard shortcut) is a child of the relevant window, so when the user closes that window, the shorcut is deleted too. Source: http://doc.qt.io/qt-4.8/objecttrees.html

quiz.question: What is the base class of everything that appears on the screen within the Qt application?

answers.txt: QWidget,
QApplication,
QGraphicsView.

quiz.hint: QWidget is the base class of everything that appears on the screen. Source: http://doc.qt.io/qt-4.8/objecttrees.html

quiz.question: What happens, when you try connect signal and slot, which are already connected (the same sender and receiver)?

answers.txt: Duplicate connection will be created, and for every signal emit() the corresponding slot will be called two times,
connect() will fail and return false; the connection will remain single,
If the connection type was Qt::UniqueConnection, the code will not compile.

quiz.hint: By default, for every connection you make, a signal is emitted; two signals are emitted for duplicate connections. You can break all of these connections with a single disconnect() call. If you pass the Qt::UniqueConnection type, the connection will only be made if it is not a duplicate. If there is already a duplicate (exact same signal to the exact same slot on the same objects), the connection will fail and connect will return false. Source: http://doc.qt.io/qt-4.8/signalsandslots.html

quiz.question: What will happen if you instantiate QVector <QWidget>?

answers.txt: The compiler will complain that QWidget's copy constructor and assignment operators are disabled,
The compiler will complain that QWidget is not registrated as meta-object,
The code will compile, but the program will result in undefined behaviour.

quiz.hint: The values stored in the various containers can be of any assignable data type. To qualify, a type must provide a default constructor, a copy constructor, and an assignment operator. If you attempt to instantiate a QList<QWidget>, the compiler will complain that QWidget's copy constructor and assignment operators are disabled. If you want to store these kinds of objects in a container, store them as pointers, for example as QList<QWidget *>. Source: http://doc.qt.io/qt-5/containers.html

quiz.question: Which one class is not a part of the QtCore?

answers.txt: QFile,
QThread,
QColor.

quiz.hint: QColor is a part of QtGui module. Source: http://doc.qt.io/qt-5/qtgui-module.html

quiz.question:
What happens when you set a parent to QObject twice, i.e. 
objectA.setParent(objectB);
objectA.setParent(objectC);

answers.txt: The objectB will stay as the parent of objectA; it's not possible to change the parent once it's set,
The pointer to objectA will be removed from objectB children list, and will be added to objectC children list,
The pointer to objectA will be present on both: objectB children list and objectC children list.

quiz.hint: Setting the parent of one object implicitly adds its address to the child list of the other, for example objA->setParent(objB); adds the objA pointer to the child list of objB. If we subsequently have objA->setParent(objC); then the objA pointer is removed from the child list of objB and added to the child list of objC . We call such an action reparenting. Source: An Introduction to Design Patterns in C++ with Qt 4, Chapter 9: QObject, Alan Ezust, Paul Ezust.

quiz.question: When a QWidget is placed inside QLayout,

answers.txt: this QLayout becomes the parent of QWidget,
this QWidget becomes the parent of QLayout,
there is no child-parent relationship between them.

quiz.hint: Widgets in a layout are not children of the layoutâ€”they are children of the widget that owns the layout. Only a widget can be the parent of another widget. Source: An Introduction to Design Patterns in C++ with Qt 4, Chapter 9.3.1: Layouts, first look, Alan Ezust, Paul Ezust.

quiz.question: Is it possible to create a class that inherits from two base classes, one of which is QObject?

answers.txt: Yes, but only if the QObject base class is put first like: class SomeClass : public QObject, public OtherClass {};
Yes, but only if the inheritance is marked as virtual,
No, multiple inheritance is not possible with QObjects.

quiz.hint: If you are using multiple inheritance, moc assumes that the first inherited class is a subclass of QObject. Also, be sure that only the first inherited class is a QObject. Source: http://doc.qt.io/qt-5/moc.html#multiple-inheritance-requires-qobject-to-be-first

quiz.question: What happens when you provide the signal body implementation?

answers.txt: Signals don't have implementation, so the code will be ignored by compiler,
The code may don't compile or don't link, depending on where the implementation was done in source code,
The implementation will overwrite usual implementation done by moc and the code will not work as intended.

quiz.hint: Code won't compile if the redundant definition (signal body) is in header. Code won't link if the redundant definition is in .cpp file. Source: tested with code.

quiz.question: Qt::ConnectionType::AutoConnection means, that

answers.txt: the slot is invoked immediately, when the signal is emitted,
the slot is invoked when control returns to the event loop of the receiver's thread,
when the sender and receiver are living in the same thread, then the slot is invoked immediately, otherwise the slot is invoked when control returns to the event loop of the receiver's thread.

quiz.hint: AutoConnection (default Qt::ConnectionType): the signal is emitted in the thread which the receiving object has affinity then the behavior is the same as the Direct Connection. Otherwise, the behavior is the same as the Queued Connection. Source: http://doc.qt.io/qt-5/threads-qobject.html#signals-and-slots-across-threads

quiz.question: Which of the following is not a Qt container?

answers.txt: QCache<Key,T>,
QSet<T>,
QMultiMap<Key,T>,
QForwardList<T>,
all of above are valid Qt containers.

quiz.hint: In the time of creating this quiz (11.2015) the QForwardList does not exist.

quiz.question: Which Qt class allows to start external program from Qt application?

answers.txt: QProcess,
QPluginLoader,
QRunnable.

quiz.hint: The QProcess class is used to start external programs and to communicate with them. Source: http://doc.qt.io/qt-5/qprocess.html

quiz.question: Choose true sentence about Qt Property system.

answers.txt: A property behaves like a class data member, but it has additional features accessible through the Meta-Object System,
A READ and WRITE accessors functions are required to create property,
Writing to properties via object->setProperty(name, value) gives better diagnostics at compile time, but it slower than setting the same values through member functions.

quiz.hint: A property behaves like a class data member, but it has additional features accessible through the Meta-Object System. Accessing a property through its WRITE accessor is the better of the two, because it is faster and gives better diagnostics at compile time, but setting the property this way requires that you know about the class at compile time. Accessing properties by name lets you access classes you don't know about at compile time. Source: http://doc.qt.io/qt-4.8/properties.html#reading-and-writing-properties-with-the-meta-object-system

quiz.question: The purpose of Qt Resource system is to provide mechanism for:

answers.txt: accessing files available on the web,
storing binary files in the application executable,
accessing binary files on the system of the end user.

quiz.hint: The Qt resource system is a platform-independent mechanism for storing binary files in the application's executable. This is useful if your application always needs a certain set of files (icons, translation files, etc.) and you don't want to run the risk of losing the files. Source: http://doc.qt.io/qt-5/resources.html
